channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹752 â€” September 12, 2025

Read on the Web

If you have any interest in music and being able to render music or generate music with JavaScript, be sure to check out the very end of this issue where we've dedicated an entire section to the topicÂ :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

How to Keep package.json Under Control â€” Staring at a 863 megabyte node_modules folder for Val Townâ€™s React app, Tom got to thinking about â€˜dependency hygieneâ€™ and some good ways to keep things under control. Good tips and tool recommendationsÂ here.

Tom MacWright

Behind the Scenes of bun install â€” Talk about an epic post. This is no mere explanation of how Bun quickly and efficiently installs packages â€” but a tour of package installation more generally, the underlying technicalities that make package installation tricky universally, and how Bun has tackled theÂ problem.

Lydia Hallie (Bun)

Stop Reinventing Forms. Use SurveyJS Instead â€” SurveyJS UI components let you build JSON-driven forms, render them in React, Angular, Vue 3, or plain JS, and store results in your own DB. Open-source, extensible, no vendor lock-in â€” save months of development and stay in control of yourÂ data.

SurveyJS sponsor

A Major Supply Chain Attack Hit the npm Ecosystem â€” Socket warned us about a phishing campaign targeting npm package publishers which, sadly, bore fruit earlier this week when a variety of popular packages became compromised (like Chalk, DuckDB's distribution for Node.js, debug, and many others).

Gooding, Brown, et al. (Socket)

RELEASES:

  • Deno 2.5 â€“ You can now create sets of permissions in deno.json, Deno.test gets some DX improvements, and deno bundle gets a programmatic API so you can script the bundling of your app, along with much more.

  • ESLint v9.35.0 â€“ Has a new rule (preserve-caught-error) for disallowing the loss of an originally caught error when re-throwing custom errors.

  • Node.js v24.8.0 (Current) â€“ Now supporting inspection of HTTP/2 network calls in ChromeÂ DevTools.

  • Electron 38 â€“ Mentioned last week, but now has an official blog post.

  • Storybook 10 is now in beta. The big change is it's going ESM only.

  • Ember 6.7, Rspack 1.5.3, Expo Router v6, Fastify 5.6

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

The Missing Link in JavaScript Tools? â€” Marvin ponders whether todayâ€™s fractured toolchain for templates, CSS imports, JSX, and numerous other non-standard enhancements to JavaScript could be unified into a singleÂ pipeline.

Marvin Hagemeister

Finally, Safe Array Methods in JavaScript â€” arr.sort() will sort your array in place, whereas ES2023â€™s arr.toSorted() will return a new, sorted copy of arr. There are several such methods you might prefer toÂ use.

Matt Smith

Secure Your Agentic Apps with Auth for GenAI â€” Secure your agentic apps with features like User Authentication for AI agents, Token Vault, and more with Auth0â€™s Auth for GenAI (exclusively in DeveloperÂ Preview).

Auth0 sponsor

An Interactive Guide to TanStack DB â€” TanStackâ€¯DB offers an embedded clientâ€‘side database that uses differential dataflow to power live, relational queries, subâ€‘ms incremental updates, and optimistic writes. This tutorial leans on using it with React, but TanStack DB works alongside Vue, Solid, and Svelte as well.

Maxi Ferreira

ğŸ“º Handling 500 Million Clicks with a $4 VPS â€“ Behind the scenes of a Node-backed site that wentÂ viral. Andrew Schmelyun

ğŸ“„ How To Set Up Express.js 5 For Production in 2025 Jan Hesters

ğŸ“„ Building Microfrontends with Module Federation and Vue Alex Opalic

ğŸ“„ How Shopify Migrated to React Native's New Architecture Thiago Magalhaes (Shopify)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Andromeda: The Newest JavaScript Runtime on the Block â€” A new JavaScript and TypeScript runtime built around the Rust-powered Nova engine. Itâ€™s still early days but theyâ€™re promising a lot: native single file compilation, a GPU-accelerated 2D Canvas API, low runtime overhead, interop with Rust, memory safety, WinterTC compatibility, and cross-platformÂ support.

Andromeda Team

BlazeDiff: 'Blazing-Fast' Pixel-by-Pixel Image Comparisons â€” The creator was happy with the established pixelmatch library for doing image comparisons, until it got too slow for the scale he wanted. Hereâ€™s the story of how he came up with a fasterÂ alternative.

Teimur Gasanov

Unlock the Power of MCP Servers â€” Clerk shows how MCP servers let AI apps access data securely with OAuth â€” complete with a Next.jsÂ demo.

Clerk sponsor

Feedsmith 2.0: Feed Parser and Generation Library â€” As well as parsing feeds, you can also create RSS, Atom, JSON Feed, and OPML files with many common namespaces (iTunes, Podcast, Media RSS, Dublin Core, etc.) Thereâ€™s a quick start tutorial for using it both in browsers or Node.js. GitHubÂ repo.

Maciej Lamberski

React Bits: 100+ Creative, Animated React Components â€” If you want a bit of visual pizzazz in your project, this is for you. The components span from a variety of text effects to general animations, a â€˜chroma gridâ€™, bouncing cards, distortions, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

David Has

  • Ink 6.3 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps, as used by Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and many other apps.

  • Tricolore 0.1 â€“ Visualize ternary compositions with choropleth maps. Live demo.

  • ts-to-zod 4.0 â€“ Generate Zod schemas (v4) from TypeScript types/interfaces.

  • Confirmal 1.3 â€“ Turn FormData into real objects with TypeScriptÂ inference.

  • ğŸ“Š Chartbrew 4.3 â€“ Create live reportingÂ dashboards.

  • ow 3.0 â€“ Function argument validation for humans.

  • uuid 13.0 â€“ Generate RFC9562 compliantÂ UUIDs.

  • Fresh 2.0 â€“ Deno-powered Web framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ”ˆ JetBrains JavaScript Day 2025 registration is now open! Get up to speed with modern JavaScript development in just one day â€“ forÂ free.

$100 off yearly Frontend Masters membership! 250+ courses, personalized learning path, workshops with devs from GitHub & Netflix. Sale ends soonÂ â†’

ğŸ—“ï¸ Free virtual DevSecCon on Oct 22, 2025. Learn to secure AI-native apps with keynotes, demos, and a developer challenge. RegisterÂ now!

ğŸµÂ Let's Get Musical

SpessaSynth: SoundFont2-Based MIDI Player and Synthesizer â€” If you think typical browser-played MIDI files sound terrible, youâ€™re right â€“ but try this! It uses a SoundFont sample driven approach to play MIDI files in a predictable fashion, and also includes an editor/visualizer if you need it. The live demo is quiteÂ striking.

Spessasus

While we're on the topic, here are some other neat music related JavaScript projects we've enjoyed over the years:

  • alphaTab â€“ A full on music notation and guitar tab rendering library for building complete musical apps (above).

  • chiptune3.js â€“ A bit like SpressaSynth (also above) but for playing module file music. Live demo.

  • Tone.js â€“ An easy way to use the Web Audio API to create music in the browser. Someone used it to recreate the famous THX 'deep note' sound.

  • ğŸ¸ SVGuitar â€“ A library to render SVG guitar chord charts.

  • JZZ.js â€“ A JavaScript MIDI library that hides a lot of complexity behind its chained syntax when you need to work directly with MIDI. (The keyboard logo at the top left of its homepage is a neat easterÂ egg.)

  • Strudel â€“ A live-coding environment in the browser for generating pieces of music with simple, chained JavaScript expressions.

ã€‘

If you have any interest in music and being able to render music or generate music with JavaScript, be sure to check out the very end of this issue where we've dedicated an entire section to the topicÂ :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

item.title: ã€Why browsers throttle JavaScript timers (and what to do about it)ã€‘ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæµè§ˆèŠ‚æ°”é—¨JavaScriptè®¡æ—¶å™¨ï¼ˆä»¥åŠè¯¥æ€ä¹ˆåšï¼‰
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹751 â€” September 5, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Mediabunny: A Complete Media Toolkit for JavaScript â€” Supporting both browsers and Node.js, this library lets you read, write and convert popular media file formats (e.g. MP4, MP3, and more) without needing to lean on dependencies like FFmpeg. You can make thumbnails, extract metadata, write code that gets converted into a video, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Vanilagy

Why Do Browsers Throttle JavaScript Timers? â€” Did you know the zero in setTimeout(0) doesnâ€™t really mean zero? Browsers clamp timers to at least a few milliseconds or more, slowing down code that relies on them. Luckily, there are alternative options, which Nolan demonstrates and benchmarks.

Nolan Lawson

Boost Coding Productivity with AI-Assisted Tools &Â Agents â€” Join Steve Kinney for this course looking at how best to harness AI for faster, higher-quality code. Learn how Cursor and Claude Code can be used to handle project plans, carry out inline edits, and perform larger background tasks â€” all adhering to the guidelines youÂ set.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Ripple: A New, In-Development TypeScript UI Framework â€” A new framework aiming to take the best parts of React, Solid and Svelte, and combine them into a single package. Notably, it comes from someone who worked on React and Svelte, as well as author of Lexical and Inferno, so itâ€™s worth a look. Thereâ€™s more info on the GitHubÂ repo.

Dominic Gannaway

IN BRIEF:

  • The What's New in Viteland: August 2025 recap presents a handy roundup of what's going on with Oxlint, Vite, Vitest, Rolldown, and related projects.

  • The Angular team has a big summer update too, covering zoneless change detection, new animation features, AI integrations, better debugging, andÂ more.

  • Thoughtbot shares its list of upcoming JavaScript conferences for 2025.

Product for Engineers Newsletter â€” Build better products, not just better code. Learn how to build features users love. Subscribe forÂ free

PostHog sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Deno's Fresh framework is now out in Fresh 2.0 Beta form. It can now optionally run as a Vite plugin which opens up numerous newÂ possibilities.

  • Electron 38.0 â€“ The cross-platform desktop appÂ framework. Now using Chromium 140 and Node 22.18 with V8Â 14.0.

  • Ember 6.6 â€“ The framework "for building ambitious web applications."

  • Node.js v20.19.5 (LTS)

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Google Chrome Turns 17: A History â€” A fantastic walkthrough of Chromeâ€™s origins and its evolution over the years. Addy looks at key milestones (multi-process architecture for example), security, its steps into the world of AI, andÂ more.

Addy Osmani

ğŸ’¡ On the topic of Chrome, Top Chrome APIs Every Developer Should Try covers a variety of Chrome-only JavaScript APIs, most of which I wasn't awareÂ of.

Lean for JavaScript Developers â€” A comprehensive introduction to Lean, a theorem prover and language for creating formally verified code that Dan Abramov has really been getting into recently. â€œIâ€™ve never written code alongside proofs like this before. HaveÂ you?â€

Dan Abramov

AI Writes Code. Wallaby MCP Makes Sure It Actually Works â€” Give your AI agent live execution data, coverage, and real-time insights to generate tests and code withÂ confidence.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Getting Accurate Text Lengths with Intl.Segmenter â€” A useful tip for when .length just isnâ€™t returning what youâ€™d quiteÂ expect..

Sangeeth Sudheer

Making XML Human-Readable Without XSLT â€” Jake gets niche, but sets JavaScript to good useÂ here.

Jake Archibald

ğŸ“„ Stress-Testing Biome's noFloatingPromises Lint Rule Dimitri Mitropoulos (Vercel)

ğŸ“„ How to Optimize Third Party Scripts with Web Workers and Partytown Jakub Andrzejewski

ğŸ“„ Redux without React: State Management in Vanilla JS Moritz KrÃ¶ger

ğŸ“„ Functional Custom Elements the Easy Way Ginger (Piccalilli)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Peaks.js 4.0: UI Component for Interacting with Audio Waveforms â€” A project originally spawned from the BBCâ€™s R&D department, Peaks renders audio waveforms to a canvas element and allows scrolling, zooming, and the sort of things you might otherwise see in an audio editor. LGPLÂ licensed.

Chris Needham et al.

ğŸ’¡ There are other options in this space too, including the newly released Waveform Renderer 1.0 (complete with interactive demo) which is entirely focused on waveform rendering, as well as Wavesurfer.js.

Redux Toolkit 2.9: The 'Batteries-Included' Toolset for Redux â€” The long-standing toolset for working with Redux for state management gets a performance update with a rewrite of RTK Queryâ€™s subscription and polling systems, automatic aborting of in-flight requests when a cache entry is removed, andÂ more.

Mark Erikson

react-window 2.0: Render Large Lists of Data Quickly â€” A component library for rendering large lists of data quickly and without the performance problems that often go along with that. There are several examples to check out, and React 18 is now required. (Tanstack Virtual is another option to consider in thisÂ space.)

Brian Vaughn

  • serverless-http 4.0 â€“ Use your existing middleware framework (e.g. Express, Koa) on AWSÂ Lambda.

  • ğŸ–‹ï¸ Signature Pad 5.1 â€“ Canvas-based smooth signature drawingÂ control.

  • Tinypool 2.0 â€“ Minimal Node.js worker thread poolÂ implementation.

  • gRPC Web 2.0 â€“ JS implementation of gRPC for browserÂ clients.

  • Jasmine 5.10 â€“ Testing framework for browsers &Â Node.

  • NodeBB 4.5 â€“ Node.js-powered forumÂ system.

  • Watt 3 â€“ Node.js application server.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸŸï¸ JetBrains JavaScript Day is back for its fifth edition! Weâ€™ve lined up a full day of great speakers and insights. All thatâ€™s missing isÂ you.

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

âœ‰ï¸Â  From the Inbox

For a variety of reasons â€“ not least taking a vacation in August (oops!) â€“ I have a backlog of fantastic submissions from people that I want to share separately:

  • ğŸ¨ Eyecons is a VS Code icon theme that automatically adapts the color of icons to fit your editor's mainÂ theme â€“ well, from this listÂ anyway.

  • TypeScript Result brings a Result type into play to help you handle errors in a more type-safe way.

  • Vue Log Arsenal is a plugin that adds a variety of logging directives for Vue 3 apps to use directly inÂ elements, like this, for example.

  • Michael Sweeney shows off 'the JavaScript equivalent of a magic trick' using functions acting as primitives and nested proxies that remember their ancestry.

  • StateLayer is a forthcoming declarative 3D component framework whose homepage is a live demo. There's also a getting started tutorial showing how to build your own 3D scene fromÂ scratch.

  • fp-filters is a curated suite of over a hundred common-use filter functions that can be used in a functional programming style.

Dan Abramov

wallabyå›¢é˜Ÿ

Sangeeth Sudheer

- ä¸Reduxä¸€èµ·å·¥ä½œçš„é•¿æœŸå­˜åœ¨çš„å·¥å…·é›†é€šè¿‡é‡å†™RTKæŸ¥è¯¢çš„è®¢é˜…å’Œè½®è¯¢ç³»ç»Ÿçš„é‡å†™ï¼Œè‡ªåŠ¨åˆ é™¤ç¼“å­˜è¾“å…¥æ—¶çš„é£è¡Œä¸­è¯·æ±‚ï¼Œæ›´å¤šã€‚

ã€‚

Mark Erikson

- ä¸€ä¸ªç”¨äºå¿«é€Ÿå‘ˆç°å¤§é‡æ•°æ®åˆ—è¡¨çš„ç»„ä»¶åº“ï¼Œè€Œæ²¡æœ‰ç»å¸¸éšä¹‹è€Œæ¥çš„æ€§èƒ½é—®é¢˜ã€‚æœ‰å‡ ä¸ªç¤ºä¾‹éœ€è¦æ£€æŸ¥ï¼Œç°åœ¨éœ€è¦React 18ã€‚ ï¼ˆ tanstack virtual æ˜¯åœ¨æ­¤ç©ºé—´ä¸­è€ƒè™‘çš„å¦ä¸€ä¸ªé€‰æ‹©ã€‚ï¼‰

Brian Vaughn

  • ğŸ–‹ï¸

item.title: ã€The latest on Oracle's hold on JavaScriptã€‘Oracleå…³äºJavaScriptçš„æœ€æ–°æŒæœ‰
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹750 â€” August 29, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

An Illustrated Guide to Big O and Time Complexity â€” A fantastic JavaScript-oriented, interactive, visual essay about Big O notation and its role in describing algorithmic complexity. This is a beautiful bit of work, even if youâ€™re already wise to O(log n) and O(n^2).

Sam Rose

ğŸ’¡ Sam is making a name for himself with his interactive essays â€“ check out the load balancing, memory allocation, hashing, and bloom filter ones too.

JavaScriptâ€™s Trademark Problem â€” Dr. Axel discusses Oracle's hold over the â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ trademark, including the history and present-day legal attempts to challenge Oracle. Fireship has also just published â–¶ï¸Â a video about the battle and thereâ€™s now a GoFundMe to raise funds to continue theÂ fight.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer et al.

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous AI Is Here â€” Meticulous creates and maintains a continuously evolving E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Built on Chromium with a deterministic engine, itâ€™s the only testing tool that eliminates flakes. Relied on by Dropbox, Notion, and Wiz.

Meticulous AI sponsor

New in ESLint v9.34.0: Multithread Linting â€” A common feature of tools like Rslint, Biome, and Oxlint, is being 'Nx times faster' than ESLint, but the latest ESLint has a trick up its sleeve and can now process multiple files at the same time, dramatically reducing lint times for largeÂ projects.

Francesco Trotta

IN BRIEF:

  • Daniel Rosenwasser proposes that TypeScript 6.0 should have --strict on byÂ default. You can learn more about what's planned for TypeScript 6.0 here.

  • Malicious versions of Nx, along with some supporting plugin packages, were published to npm â€“ more details on affected versions.

  • Remix v3 is set to drop React, instead using its own fork of Preact.

  • Codecs are a new Zod API for defining bidirectional transformations between twoÂ types.

  • ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ CascadiaJS is a conference taking place September 18-19 in Seattle,Â WA.

RELEASES:

  • Rspack 1.5 â€“ The fast web bundler improves barrel file optimization, has a faster file system watcher, improved browser support, andÂ more. It's a bigÂ release.

  • Node.js v24.7.0 (Current) â€“ A step forward for cryptography, both with Web Cryptography API support and post-quantumÂ standards.

  • Electron 37.4, Prisma 6.15.0, Ink 6.2.3

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Speeding Up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Semver â€” The latest in Marvinâ€™s multi-year series of posts on optimizing heavily used parts of the JavaScript ecosystem: â€œDuring the installation process, package managers run a bunch of semver comparisons. The semver library used in npm, yarn and pnpm can be made around 33xÂ faster.â€

Marvin Hagemeister

Say Bye with JavaScript Beacon â€” The Beacon API has been supported in all mainstream browsers for years now and provides a way to send a guaranteed (even if a page is being unloaded) non-blocking request to a web server when no response isÂ needed.

HemathKumar R

Secure Your AI Agents So That You Can Protect Your Users â€” Whether you have a B2B or B2C use case, Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security like MFA and continuous threatÂ monitoring.

Auth0 sponsor

How We Migrated Our Monorepo to Node Type Stripping â€” Since v23.6 (and in LTS since v22.18.0), Node has supported running (most) TypeScript code by stripping the types out first. One team shares the challenges encountered and what the endÂ benefitsÂ were.

Stuart Dotson (Calm)

You No Longer Need JavaScript (For Many Frontend Things) â€” A neat look at some of what plain HTML and CSS can achieve in terms of effects and techniques for which you might have once relied uponÂ JavaScript.

Lyra

ğŸ“„ Understanding Promise.any(): When One Success is Enough â€“ Given multiple promises, resolve as soon as just oneÂ fulfills. Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ The Struggle of Wrapping a JavaScript Game for Desktop â€“ The author explains why they finally settled on NW.js. JSLegendDev

ğŸ“„ Speeding Up Firefox Local AI Runtime â€“ How Firefox accelerated inference by replacing the WASM-based ONNX runtime that powers Transformers.js with a native C++ counterpart. ZiadÃ©, Adenot, and Guelton

ğŸ“„ Unit Formatting with Intl in JavaScript Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ Exporting a Cloth Simulation from Blender to an Interactive Three.js Scene Joshua Guo

ğŸ“º Coming in Angular 21: HttpClient Built In by Default Igor Sedov

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Cornerstone3D 4.0: Build Web-Based Medical Imaging Apps â€” A set of JavaScript libraries to build things like this 3D CT scan viewer, PET-CT scan viewer, and much more besides. Thereâ€™s a lot to this project, along with numerousÂ tutorials.

Open Health Imaging Foundation

ImageJS 1.0: Image Processing and Manipulation Library â€” A library for resizing, cropping, filtering, color adjustments, and numerous other image transformations which works in Node.js and the browser (supporting JPEG, PNG, BMP and TIFF â€“ thanks to pure JS dependencies like fast-jpeg and fast-png). v1.0 brings TypeScript support and a more intuitive API. GitHubÂ repo.

ImageJS Team

The Best Way for Web Developers To Track Key User Flows â€” Check out User Journeys, a new approach to connecting technical performance to user engagement in your webÂ apps.

Embrace sponsor

Obs.js: Context-Aware Web Performance for Everyone â€” Uses the Navigator and Battery APIs to get contextual information about your usersâ€™ connection strength and battery status so you can adapt your site/app to the environment or collect the data forÂ analysis.

Harry Roberts

ğŸ“ŠÂ SveltePlot: A Visualization Framework for Svelte â€” Itâ€™s still in alpha but its API is inspired by a similar plotting library by Observable and built on top of D3. There are plenty of examples in theÂ docs.

Gregor Aisch

  • Repomix 1.4 â€“ Pack an entire repository into a single, LLM-friendlyÂ file. v1.4 adds the ability to integrate commitÂ history.

  • MikroORM 6.5 â€“ TypeScript ORM for Node based on Data Mapper, Unit of Work and Identity MapÂ patterns.

  • ğŸ“„ jsPDF 3.0.2 â€“ Client-side JavaScript PDF generation for everyone.

  • Faker 10.0 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • Tiptap 3.3 â€“ Headless, framework-agnostic rich textÂ editor.

  • RxDB 16.18 â€“ Offline-first, reactive database for JSÂ apps.

  • Denops.vim 8.0 â€“ Write Vim/Neovim plugins withÂ Deno.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • Intl Playground is a handy site to get a quick look at how the different options on Intl.DateTimeFormat present in realÂ life.

  • ğŸ“º The folks who created the epic, well-produced â–¶ï¸Â Vue.js documentary, â–¶ï¸Â React documentary and â–¶ï¸Â Node.js documentary are back with â–¶ï¸Â a movie-length documentary all about Python.

  • Talking of Python, Pyodide is a port of CPython to WebAssembly that can be used both in the browser and fromÂ Node.js.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ Jeff Schomay is creating a JavaScript roguelike game called Thunder Lizard and decided to see what would happen if he used AI to turn his ASCII renders into full graphics live and on-the-fly. Fun, but soundsÂ expensive!

  • GitHub has added WebP image support across its site. It was a little flaky tillÂ now.

  • ğŸµ Need some music for programming? A fantastic design for a text-only site.

Marvin Hagemeister

â€” The Beacon API has been supported in all mainstream browsers for years now and provides a way to send a guaranteed (even if a page is being unloaded) non-blocking request to a web server whenæ²¡æœ‰ååº”æ˜¯neededã€‚

item.title: ã€We still love jQueryã€‘æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶å–œæ¬¢jQuery
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹749 â€” August 22, 2025

Read on the Web

â˜€ï¸ We're back after a week off, though I'm starting to think we should have taken two weeks off as it's been quite quiet in JavaScript-land this August! Nevertheless, we still have a full issue for you today, so let's get on to it..Â ;-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

JavaScript Weekly

Eliminating JavaScript Cold Starts on AWS Lambda â€” Porffor is a rapidly developing ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler with a major benefit being extremely quick process launch times (think sub-millisecond). This is certainly more a taste of the future, and something to experiment with, rather than something you want to imminently deploy intoÂ production.

Oliver Medhurst

Rspack Introduces Rslint, a Fast Linter Written in Go â€” A high-performance JavaScript and TypeScript linter written in Go, and the newest member of the Rspack/Rstack family ofÂ tools.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

ğŸ’¡ In related news, the Rust-powered Oxlint linter has unveiled a preview of type-aware linting support. Oxlint and Rslint (or Biome) are worth investigating if you're having performance issues with ESLint.

Front-End System Design: Build Scalable UIs â€” Learn browser rendering, DOM performance, state, and UI optimization with real-worldÂ exercises.

Frontend Masters sponsor

jQuery 4.0.0 Release Candidate 1 â€” Version 4.0 of jQuery has reached the â€œwe think this is ready; now poke it with many sticksâ€ stage. While jQuery is still heavily used, we know itâ€™s old-fashioned, but it was so important in the early days of JavaScript Weekly that we have a major soft spot forÂ it!

Timmy Willison

Reflections on the React Community â€” Lee, formerly of Vercel and widely recognized for his influence on Next.js and React, shares candid reflections on the React community, digging into the rise of React Server Components, the tension between commercial and non-commercial priorities, the toll of burnout, and a reminder that, above all, this is still a community ofÂ people.

Lee Robinson

IN BRIEF:

  • Minification Benchmarks is a frequently updated benchmark of different JavaScript minifiers, with cminify being the newestÂ addition.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ The latest js13kGames competition is underway. Submissions are due by SeptemberÂ 13.

  • ğŸ¤ Evan You, creator of Vue.js, went on the Stack Overflow podcast to talk about Vue and its ongoingÂ development.

  • Dr. Axel Rauschmayer is taking a break from his deeper technical articles to produce a series of articles for beginners â€“ he's already covered JavaScript numbers, variables, and functions, strings and methods, and arrays.

RELEASES:

  • React Native 0.81 â€“ Say hi to Android 16 support and precompiled iOSÂ builds.

  • Next.js 15.5 â€“ Turbopack builds in beta and stable Node.jsÂ middleware.

  • Bun v1.2.20 â€“ Now with reduced idle CPU usage. v1.3 dueÂ soon.

  • Astro 5.13 , ESLint v9.33.0, Fastify 5.5, pnpm 10.15, Biome 2.2

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Using the Custom Highlight API â€” The CSS Custom Highlight API offers a way to style text ranges on a document using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to style them. And, as of Firefox 140, all major browsers now support it. This could be great for in-page search or even dynamic syntaxÂ highlighting.

Chris Coyier

The Power of the Intl API: A Definitive Guide to Browser-Native Internationalization â€” Instead of relying on heavy third-party libraries, modern browsers provide JavaScript with the Intl API â€” a powerful, native way to handleÂ internationalization.

Fuqiao Xue

The Best Way for Web Developers to Track Key User Flows â€” Check out User Journeys, a new approach to connecting technical performance to user engagement in your webÂ apps.

Embrace sponsor

Designing Chrome's Built-in AI Web APIs â€” Domenic, a member of the Chrome team at Google, shares some insights into how the APIs around Chromeâ€™s newest AI features wereÂ designed.

Domenic Denicola

â–¶Â Â React Mock Interview: Three Devs Take on a Challenge â€” Three top developers take on the same React challenge to build a form complete with validation. If youâ€™ve got the time for a 50 minute video, this is fun andÂ educational.

Shruti Kapoor

ğŸ“„ How Incorrect Shopify Webhook Parsing Led to Database Deletion â€“ A sneaky problem with an unexpected undefined value being fed to Prisma. One of Prismaâ€™s validation errors did pick it up, however. Ingressr

ğŸ“„ The Problems with Modals, and How to Solve Them in Vue.js Noel De Martin

ğŸ“„ How Bun Made postMessage 500x Faster Jarred Sumner

ğŸ“„ The Future of JavaScript: What Awaits Us JSDev

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Uppy 5.0: A Powerful, Modular JavaScript File Uploader â€” Upload not just from local sources (whether files or a webcam) but also remote services like Dropbox or Google Drive. Integrates with frameworks like React, Vue, Svelte, and Angular, and supports resumable uploads too. GitHubÂ repo.

Transloadit

ğŸ˜„Â Faceclick: A Lightweight Emoji Picker with Keyword Search â€” Includes some interesting details on how it was made moreÂ efficient.

Dave Gauer

Secure Your AI Agents So That You Can Protect Your Users â€” Whether you have a B2B or B2C use case, Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security like MFA and continuous threatÂ monitoring.

Auth0 sponsor

Sidequest.js: A New Scalable Job Execution Option for Node.js â€” A scalable background job processor for Node apps that includes a Web-based dashboard, the ability to support multiple backends, and TS-first ergonomics. GitHub repo.

Merencia and Guizzo

Minecraft MCP Server: Let an LLM Take Control of Minecraft â€” A fun way to play around with MCP servers and LLMs. It uses Mineflayer, a JavaScript API for creating Minecraft bots, behind the scenes. The video in the README is cool, showing how Claude and this server can turn a photo of the White House into an in-worldÂ creation.

Yuniko Software

  • Waku 0.25 â€“ The minimal React framework introduces the concept of 'slice components' â€“ a new approach to fine-grained componentÂ rendering.

  • Retire.js 5.3 â€“ A security scanning tool to detect the use of JavaScript libraries with known vulnerabilities in yourÂ project.

  • Ky 1.9 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.

  • Repomix 1.3 â€“ Pack an entire repository into a single, LLM-friendlyÂ file.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ React Date Picker 8.6 â€“ Simple date picker component.Â (Demo.)

  • Flatbush 4.5 â€“ Fast static spatial index for 2D points andÂ rectangles.

  • plotly.js 3.1 â€“ Standalone data visualization library.

  • Chai 6.0 â€“ BDD / TDD assertionÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ¤– Faster AI data = smarter agents. Redis 8.2 brings vector sets and search with sub-ms speed. Try it forÂ free.

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • SmallJS is a Smalltalk-80 implementation that compiles to JavaScript. v1.7 has just been released with support for creating desktop apps usingÂ NW.js.

  • ğŸï¸ Ryan Skinner presents Rari, a demonstration of replacing Node.js with a Rust-powered backend for rendering React server components, and shows off some serious performanceÂ improvements.

  • ğŸš´ Harry Roberts analyzed the performance of the sites for each team in the Tour de France â€“ it's interesting to see some of the things heÂ noticed.

  • If you use AWS at all, this list of 'AWS stuff you think you know that's now wrong' from Corey Quinn is an eye-opener.

  • /^a(1,3)/ == /^(a|aa|aaa)/? A regex equivalence checker.
